<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 361, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2024 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 605]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 213, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 712, 907, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 867, 727, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 90]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 97, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 594, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 134, 500, 152]]<|/det|>
Connect the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 160, 714, 319]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 333, 534, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 178, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 364, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
**Ensure that the polarities of the power supply, component C and the voltmeter are as shown in Fig. 1.1.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 178, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 591, 431]]<|/det|>
Close switch S for a short time and then open it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 175, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 544, 462]]<|/det|>
Watch the voltmeter reading as it reduces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 833, 492]]<|/det|>
When the voltmeter reading passes a value \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) of \(8.00\mathrm{V}\), start the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 804, 523]]<|/det|>
When the voltmeter reading passes a value of \(7.00\mathrm{V}\), stop the stop-watch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 176, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 535, 895, 554]]<|/det|>
Record the starting value \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) and the time \(T\) for the voltmeter reading to fall by 1.00V.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 599, 917, 617]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{S}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 751, 917, 768]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ............................................................$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 766, 920, 785]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Choose another starting value \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\). Close S for a short time and then open it. Measure the time \(T\) for the voltmeter reading to fall by \(1.00\mathrm{V}\) from the starting value \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 591, 137]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 145, 687, 170]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{T}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 597, 143, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 594, 175, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 591, 660, 621]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{T}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 597, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 628, 180, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 628, 457, 647]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 660, 180, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 660, 608, 679]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 848, 917, 867]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 880, 917, 898]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 895, 920, 913]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 739, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 99, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 702, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a wooden rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 133, 611, 152]]<|/det|>
● Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
● Adjust the apparatus so that the wooden rod is parallel to the bench and the spring is vertical.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 203, 850, 628]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 640, 591, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 823, 689]]<|/det|>
● The distance between the ends of the spring is \(L_0\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 702, 430, 720]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 745, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<form>L_0 = .................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 72, 215, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Pull the mass hanger down a short distance and then release it. The mass hanger will oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 220, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 117, 715, 135]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to find the period \(T\) of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 274, 922, 293]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 307, 180, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 306, 641, 325]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value of the spring constant \(k\) using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 330, 534, 359]]<|/det|>
\[k = \frac{\alpha\pi^2}{T^2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 368, 398, 387]]<|/det|>
where \(\alpha = 0.800 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 462, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
<form>k = .................................................... N m⁻¹

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 495, 215, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 494, 880, 514]]<|/det|>
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 72, 210, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Move the stand supporting the spring away from the other stand and add the plumb line, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 112, 823, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 481, 591, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 511, 215, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
Adjust the apparatus so that the angle \(\theta\) between the spring and the vertical is approximately \(20^{\circ}\) and the wooden rod is parallel to the bench, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 559, 213, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 559, 855, 578]]<|/det|>
The new distance between the ends of the spring is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 590, 423, 607]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 619, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ....................................................... m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 651, 220, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 651, 423, 670]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... \(\diamond\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 698, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 727, 181, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 727, 811, 746]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(\theta\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 883, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................. % [1]
